H0.text: Requires energy is not a characteristic common to organisms.

H1.text: Reproduction is not a characteristic common to organisms.

H2.text: Rigidity is not a characteristic common to organisms.

H3.text: Presence of DNA is not a characteristic common to organisms.

A4.text: Living things require energy for homeostasis and other activities.

A5.text: Reproduction: the ability to produce new individual organisms, either asexually from a single parent organism or sexually from two parent organisms.

A6.text: Most animals (including humans) and plants reproduce sexually.

A7.text: Sexually reproducing organisms have different sets of genes for every trait (called alleles).

A8.text: DNA is a polymer composed of two polynucleotide chains that coil around each other to form a double helix.

A9.text: DNA contains the genetic information that allows all forms of life to function, grow and reproduce.

A10.text: The basal metabolic rate of an organism is the measure of the amount of energy consumed by all of these chemical reactions.

A11.text: Most of the structures that make up animals, plants and microbes are made from four basic classes of molecules: amino acids, carbohydrates, nucleic acid and lipids (often called fats).

A12.text: Rigidity (neurology), an increase in muscle tone leading to a resistance to passive movement throughout the range of motion.

A13.text: Rigidity (psychology), an obstacle to problem solving which arises from over-dependence on prior experiences.

A14.text: Real rigidity and nominal rigidity refer to the resistance of prices and wages to market changes in macroeconomics.
